title: 111_hr4855
content: The "Work-Life Balance Award Act" establishes definitions for terms like employer, work-life balance policy, and Secretary of Labor. It aims to promote workplace practices that enable employees to achieve a satisfactory work-life balance. The Work-Life Balance Award is established by the Department of Labor for employers with work-life balance policies. Employers can apply for the Award through the Work-Life Balance Advisory Board and reapply regardless of previous receipt. Recipients' names will be displayed on the Secretary's website. The Secretary (or designee) presents the Work-Life Balance Award annually to employers meeting the criteria developed by the Board. Names of recipients are available on the Department of Labor's website. The Work-Life Balance Advisory Board is established. The Work-Life Balance Advisory Board is established within the Department of Labor to develop criteria for determining recipients of the Award, considering work-life balance policies and employer compliance with labor laws. The Work-Life Balance Advisory Board is responsible for determining Award recipients, developing application processes, recommending recipients, presenting names to the Secretary, and setting an annual timetable. The Board can revise criteria with the Secretary's approval and membership is subject to appointment guidelines. The Work-Life Balance Advisory Board consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including a chairperson representing the public, members from government, nonprofit employers, private industry, labor organizations, and families and children. Recommendations for board members are made by the Speaker and minority leader of the House of Representatives. The Work-Life Balance Advisory Board consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, with recommendations from key government officials. Members must have knowledge and experience in work-life balance policies, and political affiliation is limited to ensure diversity. Each member serves a 2-year term, with specific exceptions. The Work-Life Balance Advisory Board members are appointed for 2-year terms, with the possibility of reappointment. Initial appointees serve either a 2-year or 3-year term as designated by the Secretary. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the predecessor's term. Board operations include regular meetings. The Board shall meet at the call of the Chairperson or a majority of its members within 90 days of all members' appointment. A majority of members constitute a quorum for voting and establishing rules by majority vote. The Secretary may prescribe regulations to carry out the purposes of this Act.
